Psalm 84th[sto]  Delivered Aug 3. 1794
Along society Nov 9th
How amiable are thy [sic] Thy Tabernacles, O Lord of Hosts. --
The writer of this psalm is supposed
to be the man after God's own heart.
It is supposed also, that he composed it,
in his exile from the Tabernacle
& worship of God, occasioned by the
conspiracy & rebellion of his Son Absalom -- 
In this affected situation
he expresses the pious affection, and
breathing of his soul to God, in the
fifth & second verses of this psalm
How amiable are thy Tabernacles
O Lord of Hosts -- My soul longeth,
yea, even fainteth for the courts of the
Lord -- My heart & my flesh crieth
out for the living God -- These ardent desires of the psalmists heart.

toward these objects - express the elevation
of his piety - and sat before us in a stricking point of light,
the general nature of christian exercises
under all similar circumstances.
In the words of the text are noticable two particulars --
1st The object of the Pmst admiration (viz) the Tabernacle --
This [word stricken] building was set up
by a pattern immediately given
by the Lord of Hosts himself the God of Israel.
it was dedicated wholly his immediate
service, & he owned it for his habitation - And hence it is [unknown word], thy Tabernacles  O Lord of Hosts --
it is expressed, plurally (most probably) in reference
merely to t[he] different apartments contained in it, & the different services assigned
to each of them--
2ndly We may notice in what respect

this object is declared to be admirable
(viz) in its beauty -- also a delight &
pleasure  enjoyed in it; How amiable 
this is --  how desirable  are
thy Tabernacles O Lord -- the delight
& satisfaction they are capable of affording
is not eve to be expressed,
The obseration [sic] which naturally
arises from the text is this (viz)  To
the people of God, his temples are very
amiable or desirable  --
In attending to this observation it is
proposed to contemplate only t[he] reasons
why t[he] temples of t[he] Lord of Hosts are
so desirable by all t[he] children of God --
To which will be added some reflections -- 
The reasons why t[he] temples of [unknown]
or t[he] Lord of Hosts are so desirable to
all his children may be all comprehended in two general ones -- (viz) The

privileges which are set forth or manifested in these temples -- & secondly
their hearts being prepared by t[he] spirit
of God to relish & be delighted with these
privileges -- These are t[he] two general
reasons why they are so amiable and
desirable -- The latter of these reasons
why the temples of God are to desirable
to his children - (viz) that their hearts
are prepared by t[he] spirit of G. to relish
those privileges is necessarily supposed
[word faded and struck through] without this they would
not be his children -- the privileges of 
t[he] sanctuary would not be delightsome [sic]
-- they would not give them a divine
seraphic pleasure -- on t[he] other hand these
privileges would be tasteless, dull, and
wearisome -- In t[he] language of t[he] [Pht?]
Behold their ear is uncircumcised - & they
cannot hearken: behold t[he] word of the
Lord is unto them a reproach they have
no delight in it -- [Bast?] all [Gfs?]

true children or people being prepared by his spirit
have a feeling
in unison with t[he] [?mist?]: Say he
my soul longeth, yea, even fainteth
for t[he] courts of t[he] Lord -- This preparation
therefore being understood, it
will not not be necessary to dwell upon this part
of t[he] subject -- The
first general reason why t[he] Temples
of God are so desirable to his children
(viz) on acct of t[he] privileges which
are manifested in them need attention
The inquisitive mind wishes to know
what are some of those privileges
These will be mentioned in six pas[unknown] each of wh. make t[he]
sanctuary of God very amiable & [word struck through and faded]
desireable to his people and
1st? Gd Jesus, who is t[he] Lord of Hosts
always dwells in a gracious manner in such places & temples as he

owns for his -- & there meets his people
The Lord of Hosts dwelt in the
Tabernacle by his gracious presence
[word struck through and faded] in a pillar of a cloud
In t[he} same manner also he entered
into t[he] temple built by Solomon --
These tabernacles he owned for his -
Of the latter it is said, And the
Lord appeared to Solomon & said
Now have I chosen & sanctified
this house that my name may
be there forever: & mine eye and
mine heart shall be there perpetually -- 
If thou wilt walk before
me as David thy Father walked
& do according to all that I have
commanded thee -- In t[he] gospel
day we find that God is pleased
[several words scratched out] to honor any
place or temple with his gracious
presence when his people meet
for his service says he where two
or three are met in my name there

am I in the midst -- But more
especially is he present in Temples where his
people steadily resort & attend most
comformably to his will, in all his institutions -- 
He walks, amidst his golden candlesticks - & says in the
language of t[he] prist? This is my rest forever, here will I dwell for I have
desired it -- & he loveth t[he] gates of
Zion more than all the dwellings
of Jacob -- Now t[he] privilege of meeting God & 
enjoying t[he] manifestations
wh he makes of himf. to his disciples
is esteemed by them of infinitely greater value

than all things besides.

To see the thing of Glory in his beauty
is pleasant beyond description -- Says
David O God my soul thirsteth for
for thee -- my flesh longeth for thee
in a dry & thirsy land where no water is To see
thy power & thy glory
so as I have seen thee in t[he] Sanctu[ary]

[Sanc]uary -- This seeing of God in t[he] sanctuary hides
t[he] [lusture?] of every other
object & depreciates every other kind
of enjoyment so much that they are
not to be mentioned as bearing any
proportion to t[he] nature of this --
On [unknown] of this privilege of meeting God [unknown] temples are very
[word scratched out] amiable & desirable: --
2ndly they not only meet God in his
sanctuary & behold his glory -- but
they are admitted free access to him
in prayer -
says the Apos in with the Father and
with his Son Jesus Ct -- In this communion by prayer - 
They have opportunity to present before Ct. immediately the
whole compass of their desires concerning thems for time & eternity -- likewise t[he] 
whole compass of their desires
concerning their nearest friend & dearest
objects around them -- & likewise their
desires concerning the chh [abbreviation of "children"? or church] of God and
all mankind - and all this with the

most perfect assurance of being heard and answered in every proper desire and wish. Ct. says that 18th-19th. If two of you shall agree on earth as touching{?] anything they shall ask - it shall be done for them of my father who verily I say unto you whatsoever ye shall ask the Father in my name he will give it you. Now this privilege of communion with Ct. in the places where he meets his children, is unspeakably great. Ct. says by his [Sp?] I will make them joyful in my house of prayer. How pleasant and delightsome must it be to commune with him who is Father of their spirits and

[unclear] This seeing of Ct. in a [unclear] hides a [unclear] of every other object and depreciates every other kind of enjoyment so much that they are not to be mentioned as bearing any proportion to a nature of this on acct of this privilege of meeting Ct. His temples are very amiable and desirable
2) They not only meet Ct. and behold his glory but also have the privilege of holding communion with him by prayer. Our communion says the [Apo.?] is with the Father and with his son Jesus Ct. In this communion by prayer they have opportunity to [unclear] before Ct. immediately whole compass of their desires concerning them. For time and eternity - likewise a compass of their desires concerning their nearest friends and dearest objects around them - & likewise their desires concerning the [unclear] of God and mankind and all this with the

most perfect assurance of being heard and answered in every proper desire and wish. Ct. says Mat. 18th.19th - If two of you shall agree on earth as touching anything they shall ask - it shall be done for them of my Father who is in Hn. This reflects social prayer in who his people are agreed - & concerning any matter in who they shall mutually agree to lay before him. He says again by Holy Ghost - before they call I will answer, while they are yet speaking I will hear saith the Lord - & again "Verily verily I say unto you whatsoever ye shall ask the Father in my name he will give it you. Now this privilege of communion with Ct. in the places where he meets his children, is unspeakably great. Ct. says by his Spr.? I will make them joyful in my house of prayer - How pleasant & delightful must it be to commune with him who is t? Father of their spirits - and

him who has redeemed them fr eternal destruction by his blood - how pleasant to find him caring for all their afflictions - entering into all their joys & sorrows & comforting them with a token of his mercy & love? How comforting to leave all t. concerns of their dearest connections in his hand, to leave the conflicts & distresses of his chh with him who is perfect in wisdom & cannot err. How safe to leave in his hands a world lying in wickedness - These instances together with their almost infinite connections, in who the children of Ct hold communion with him in prayer, make t. place of his sanctuary very amiable and desirable.
3dly In the sanctuary of Ct. refreshes his children with all necessary instruction concerning their duty to him. These instructions they receive with a spiritual disernment & relish

Divine truth, in its various subjects & connection proves a quickening word to them - All divine truths honor God - this gives the joy - the way of salvation it overcomes them with unspeakable qualitive - all circumstances in the plan of salvation and persecution of it shine in their view, with the wisdom and infinite mercy of God- and hence their hearts burn within them as the disciples going to Emmaus- the word of God, one spirit and life - It is a quickless word, by which theirafectio and graces are enlivened, and strengthen- and enabled more vigorously to uplift the temptation who left them for the wolrd, the felsh and Satan - Hence says the swift they word is sweeter to one than the honey and the honey comb - Here after they find the

& they with him. These outward signs wash away no sin, nor make any atonement - they are designed to express outwardly benefits purchased? by Cts. body & blood: and to represent & confirm application of those benefits previously applied to t. heart. In these ?ealing? transactions how infinitely unworthy do his children feel:yet how joyful? Most deeply distressed with a sense of sin, they rise proportionally in holy admiration of redeeming love -That sovereign love wh. saves them fr. the depths of misery - By these outward solemn transactions between God & their own souls, they grow confirmd in the blessings of t gospel & live upon t hidden manna - they live by that bread wh. came down from Hv wh. gives life to all who partake

..ity to submission to Mkd? lawful authority & benevolence to all - In t sanctuary Ct dwells as a purifier of sin by his word -as a  fountain for cleansing by his atonement & as a well of water for refreshment & satisfaction: He says by his Spirit the Lord hath chosen Zion: he hath desired it for his habitation: This is my wish forever: herewith I dwell for I have desired it - I will abundantly bless her provisions, and I will satisfy her poor with bread. I will also clothe her priests with [unclear]; & her saints shall shout aloud for joy -How grt is this privilege of enthu..tion? & quickening received fr. t. oracles of divine truth? A life of experience can only teach it
4thly In the sanctuary Ct.seals his covenant with his people - by his sacriments. Here He sups with them

of it. This privilege of supping with Ct. & giving all to him, in covenant & receiving a taste & confirmation of all spiritual blessings, is beyond expression. This makes t. temples of Ct desirable & beautiful
5th In t. sanctuary where Ct dwells is t birthplace of saints - says Ct by his Spi? of Zion it shall be said this & that man, was born in her & t. highest himf. shall establish her. The Lord shall count - when he writeth up the people - that this man was born there- This is a matter of unspeakable joy to his people: there is joy in Hn  over one sinner that repenteth - equally so here among t people of God -  according to their grace & knowledge of it. Instances of this nature give fresh vigor, refreshment & comfort as shows the power of Ct. as plainly as to raise

t dead . It shows the truth of his promise that his cause? shall never fail & that no opposion? of earth or hell shall prevent t accomplishments of all his glorious designs of saving all who repent. This continued miracle in raising men spiritually dead to life is a mean of confirmation who invigorates to faith of his people & excites peculiar animation. To mention but one more. In the sanctuary is t place where the people of God enjoy t greatest communion with t chh above - in their praises and halalujahs to God. Here is t place where they gain new strength to gloryfy God - & prepare for Hn. These privileges made t people feel t amiableness & beauty of Ct's  tabernacles & to say Blessed are they that dwell in thy house -

measure will feel as the people? they will say, O God How amiable are thy tabernacles My soul longeth yea even fainteth for the court of the Lord my heart & my flesh without? for thee.  3d We see likewise the gratitude wh. becomes those to express who are about to be blessed with the privileges for wh. they long.

Blessed is t man whose strength is in thee; in whose heart are t ways of thee. They go fr strength to strength; everyone in Zion appeareth before God. For a day spent in they court is better than a thousand. I had rather be a door keeper in t house of my God than to dwell in t tents of wickedness.
Improvement - If the privileges to be enjoyed in the sanctuary of Ct. are so great & calculated to give his children such happiness; then see that those who are blessed with a tabernacle of worship when they can statedly? enjoy these privileges are infinitely favored
2d - If t privileges of Cts sanctuary are so grt & desirable then we see that those who are deprived of them in any

Pm [unclear] 72d - 6th  delived.  June 7 ?/95  July 20 1806
He shall come down like rain upon t mown grass, as showers that water t earth. These words are supposed to represent t influences of the Holy Spirit refreshing t souls of God's children. In order to contemplate them with improvement it is necessary to consider two particulars -
I.Wherein mown grass or the earth represent the hearts of men 
II. Where rain and shower falling upon earth and grass represent t influences of the

spirit falling on t hearts of men. To which will be added an improvement
I . We are to consider wherein mown grass or earth represent t hearts of men. And st? In their surroundings - The field wh. is laid waste by t mower. Scythe presents a barren prospect. The remaining stalks appear as if they would never revive under the scorching beams of t sun [doodle] The earth likewise in its simple natural state is barren, it knows no such thing as pleasant fruits, grass, grain, herbs, fruit & trees grow not upon it spontaneously, so also t hearts of men - they are utterly destitute of right affections toward God

These grow not spontaneously the fruits off spirit which appear in right affections of t heart, & guide all the faculties of men in a way of obedience to God do not spring from  this soil- not t least possible fruit of this kind is to be seen. But the natural heart like t barren earth produces only weed, nettles, briars & thorns of sin, its affections are corrupt. They lead them to break every holy duty & commit. doodle So the natural hearts of men are barren of any good fruit, ever since sin entered t world [unclear] glory has departed. They have nothing but barrenness left. They have no love, delight, joy, peace & comfort in God. They have no holy gratitude, trust or submission to God. They have no true repentance, faith, hope or christian humility. They  have no patience, fortitude or resignation to divine will or any other gr..ne?

sin without cesation – It is like uncultivated wilderness, when every tree, plant, or shrub grows wild – & every ravenous beast, bird, & serpent have their hiding? places, & barren to the fruitless waste – The ?atheral? heart, destitute of holiness & fraught with evil defies, wild imaginations ungovernable passions pride, malice, envy, avarice and hypocricy may well be, unclear It's barren of all good – & yields only poisenous productons?, to t barren earth or unclear  2dly - The mown grass and ? frequently in a posithing? condi=   they frequent a barren prospect - the faculties of t soul in their depraved state - like t remaing stalks of grass do not appear as if they could ever bear holy fruit - the faculties of the soul appear ruined - as if they were once noble, but now are ruined - The field looks as if there was once fruit, but now is barren, so the soul -

Zion under the burning heat of the sun - As the stalks of grass after the mower appear withering scorched and lifeless - so the natural heart often appears disconsolate & Joyless  under a sense of its sins, & the wrath of God - Outward enjoyments now, are ?afteless? and burdensome - a fearful looking for of Judgment & fiery indignation awakens the most distressing fears - The terror of t Lord take hold - & t guilty soul finds nothing to shelter it fr. impending wrath; except God's abused? sovereignty - The hope from its own righteousness is cut off & every refuge of deception fails - it withers

like the mown grass.
The earth also parched with the sun represents the natural heart under affliction - When God is pleased to take away earthly comforts, such as near friends - children, property, or reputation - the springs of Joy to t natural man are dried up - so also when sickness wastes his strength & appetite, & makes him a burden to himself, then his Joys and comfort are dried up as the earth is dried of its moisture - he is in a famishing condition - his sorrows shroud him in sackcloth & he sits in t region & shadow of death - Again - The earth may illustrate the natural heart in one more respect - . As it is barren

of good fruit & often his is a parched condition under t. heat of the sun so also it is frequently very hard & rocky - The natural heart, destitute of grace is hard like a rock - or encrusted ground. no seed, trees, or plants can fall into or grow on the rock - or parched ground, so no seeds of divine truth - precepts or commands - providences or calls of God can enter a natural heart or impress it so, as it shall receive it & bring forth fruit. So the Holy Spirit (Zechariah 7.12) They made their hearts as an adament stone least they shant hear the same & t words which t Lord of hosts hath sent in his spirit by a former ppt -

Who are repeatedly called upon to break up ther fallow ground, & to sow not among thorns - meaning, t. parched ground of t. heart, which receives not t. seed of divine truth - The stony ground hearers? were the stony in heart Thus we see the mown grass & t earth represent t hearts of natural men in their barrenness of spiritual fruits - their destress & Joyless state under a sense of God's wrath, & outward affliction, & also their harness is [repthing?]] & warding off all true con..ithon? of sin, & impressions from divine truth - 
IIdly [secondly]  We were to confiser? wherein showers falling upon t earth & grass represent t influ[ence]

of the Holy Spirit falling upon the hearts of men and ? unclear--scribbled out
As t showers of rain fall up on t dry ground freely without expence to any, unclear--scribbled out So Ct Jesus in the influence of his spirit comes down upon t hearts of men freely of his own accord - and free of all expense to mankind   He comes without money, & without & without price -  Again he sends his rain on one city & not on another -
Ct. Jesus knew, from t beginning who those were who should believe - among those some are wise men - Some mighty, & some noble, just to show that he acts without resthaints? but the principal part? are the foolish

in t eye of t world t. weak t. base - t. despised & such as are not accounted of at all as making any figure? in unclear unclear--marked out
But are considered as worthless & vile  Upon these scattered up & down among t. mass of men, Ct. sends down t. rain of his spirit, without their meniting? t. least possible degree of it they deserve in stead there of the wrath of God - But Ct send down his spirit freely of his own good pleasure & it comes upon them irrepithably?, when, & under whatever circumstance, he pleases
2dly As t. rain & showers fall plentifully & repeatedly So does Ct.  shed? down his spirit plentifully & repeatedly upon his children -
He says I will pour water upon him that is thirsty & flood up the dry ground  I will pour out my spirit up

thy seed - The dry ground of their hearts, he will abundantly water, with t. rain of his spirit
In proportion, to their necessity will he supply them with shower after shower -
3dly  The earth who drinketh in t rain unclear

3dly As t. rain falls upon the
earth in various ways sometimes

without noise or violence. So
Ct. descends by his influences in almost

he comes in t. most destressing

see t. tempest of GoD's wrath

law, they tremble through fear

of what is to come their troubled thoughts, and dark tumultuous feelings drive them almost to despair - Sometimes he comes in dethessing? providence, & unclear--marked out lays all their comforts waste by his flood & deep waters - he causes his billions to roll over them - & sometimes he comes in t. soft whispers of confirence?;  & shed abroad his grace & draws them sweetly to him..
The small rain, & dew of his mercy captivates them before they are aware - Now Ct. falling upon his childrens hearts, by t. influences of his Spirit in a free - sovereign - plentiful & various ways suited their various situations 
We may readily conclude t

effects of his coming down upon them in these ways would be equally conspicuous -
As t. rain & showers falling plentifully upon t. barren dry earth, & mown grass refresh them & make them soft & fruitful unclear--marked out, so Ct. coming into t. hearts of his  children by his influences softens their hearts, & makes them fruitful of all holy graces & obedience
He changes them from nature to grace
The most Barren Witness is turned into a fruitful field, a witness where everything grew wild is turned into a garden of pleasant fruits  The briars & thorns of malicious passions are crucified or removed fr. t. heart - the habits of sin, are destroyed by degrees & t. plants of righteousness grow & florish - they increase in fruits of love  -repentance, faith & hope, godly fear - humility, patience - submis -sion

submission, & gratitude these appear in their beauty -
The unclear--marked out stony heart is made soft by these showers of divine influence; & receives t. seed of divine truth, & brings forth fruit
No heart so rocky no ground so dry, & hard, but what the allpowerful operation of Cts spirit can revive in it, t fruits of holiness - & make them grow unclear--marked out Again 
As t. showers of rain upon t. earth revive the fruits causing them to spring unclear--marked out & grow stronger, putting unclear--marked out on a unclear--marked out beautiful appearance

so also do t influences of the Spirit increase the graces of t children of God- By these, they grow more & more established rooted & grounded in love, unclear--marked out- they are like trees planted by t water-courses - they are fresh & flourishing -
Every fresh shower makes every grace thrive
the heart is comforted, unclear--marked out hope is strengthened - faith is quickened - prayer enlivened & the soul made healthy & t. land made obedient. The field or heart where naught but sin, & Thistles grew and every beast of prey or a friend of darkness has him? unclear; even here nature smiles in new-created life & shoots of new birth unclear--marked out What remains

shall be only some reflections from t whole - and turn to t. middle 
2dly If Ct. by t. influences of his Spirit unclear--marked out & produces effects in his children similar t. those in t. natural world by t falling of rain on t. earth or mown grass, then, we may see why so many people continue dry & destitute of any spiritually good fruits - Ct. has not come down upon them irrepstably? in t. showers of his grace. unclear--marked out They remain as yet in their naturally barren unclear--marked out hard dry, state
for wise reasons Ct. lets them alone to fill up t measure of their sins- But here lest some should complain it is to be observed that Ct. rains by his influence & grace upon

all men, so it would be sufficient for their salv - if they did not resist it - & shed it off
Indeed t. seed of t word does fall into their hearts - they hear externally t. truth of t gospel & Ct. convicts their consciences that it is true - & gives them t. offer of life but their hearts are opposed, & they resist the spirit with wh. he strives with them -
Says t apostle t earth that drinketh in t. rain that cometh off upon it & bringeth forth herbs, meat for those by whom it is dressed, receiveth blessing from God
But that which beareth briers & thorns is rejected & is right unto ?sing? whose end, is to be burned? - Here notice the earth that drinketh in t rain that cometh off upon it -
The earth here represents t hearts of

all men - good & bad - its drinking in t rain that cometh off upon it means t. hearts of men which receive t. knowledge of t truth, & t impulses of t. Holy Spirit. As t. rain is continually (i.e. often falling upon t earth, so the truths of t gospel are often falling into t hearts of men, and Ct. attends these truths with t influence of his spirit. Now t. apostle noticed t effects - such earth or hearts as bear t fruits of holiness - suitable for Ct who bestows this grace/rain: These hearts receive blessing from God. But that ground or those hearts which under t rain of Cts grace bears nothing but briers & thorns i.e. sins of opposition against? t. truth unclear of unbelief, pride, & stoutness?

such hearts as they are nigh  unto

I st We are to consider what we are to understand by christian conversation -  By t frequent use of this word in scripture we are to understand by it intercourse such as takes place in social life - between States & ?

But further - the word conversation in t. text is supposed to take place, among christians or true believers on - The apostle diverts this epistle to t Holy brethren, partakers of t Hvnly calling" & he addresses them in this last chapter as being of t same description? - & Says let brotherly Love continue & c the brotherly Love here exhorted to was? christian love  The love enjoined? in t second commandment "Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself"  He exhorts to let it continue, & grow, & be perfected, & after speaking of one or two other moral duties as expressions of this love - He mentions the text as an expression of t same - Let your conversation & c let your mutual intercourse be christian built upon the law of brotherly love  So that it was evidently intended

to be christian conversation - as it may likewise further appear from the next thing designed for consideration - (viz)
II d When may christian conversation be sd to be without covetousness   Christian conversation may be sd to be without covetousness when it takes place in simplicity & godly sincerity - together with a submissive, quiet resignation to the divine will in possessing no more than God has seen fit to bestow upon us -  Says the apostle "having the testimony of our consscincis? that in simplicity & godly sincerity (not by fleshly? ?issan? but by t grace of God we have had our conversations in t world."  Here the apostle defines ?ishin? conversation from his own example, to be such intercourse with t world as was, in

simplicity & godly sincerity - & this being effected as through the grace of God - (i.e.) He was enabled to practice the law of brotherly love in his traffic, in his kindness - in his charity - in his conversation of every kind - "All things what soever he wants that others should do to him, he has done even so to them" And further unclear he has learned in whatever state he was therewith to be content" He was resigned to the will of God in not posessing more and want things that he had - And so in t text he recommends the same to his brothers - "& be content with such things as ye have - This observation was added merely to define christian conversation, t. more precisely, To be discontented with t gifts

of God - would be covetous - it would be repining agt God & lead into grt temptations This mode of Christian conversation, or intercourse with one another talking place in simplicity & godly sincerity, together with a quiet submissive resignation to divine will in prophesying no more that God sees fit to bestow upon us -Is not designed to encourage sloth & indolence, or a careless neglect of ourselves and families insert mark this wants contradict other passages - But that we should be so content as not  to do any thing contrary to brotherly love or contrary to our own personal purity, in order to obtain more. I Timothy 4th-8th    August 3d 1800 Delivered
But godliness is profitable
unto all things, having promise
of the life that now is, & of that
which is to come.
In attending to these words
it is proposed to consider
Ist What is meant by godliness &
IIdly shew wherein it is profitable
unto all things, having promise
of the life that now is, and
that which is to come.
Godliness is used in our text
to signify the sum of true religion.-
or the sum of that
duty which God requires of man.
Says the apostle to Timothy
Exercise thyself unto godliness" (i.e.)
practice true religion_ exercise
yourself to love God with all your

heart, & your neighbour as
yourself_ This duty of love
to God & man, is godliness_ but
it is that which God requires- or
it is the exercise of that benevolence
which is like God the fountain
of moral excellence & perfection- 
Further- Godliness
extends to all the ways in which
love is commanded to be exercised
in the law or gospel- Says the
same apostle to Timothy "the word
of our Lord Jesus Christ, & the doctrine
which is according to godliness, are
to be preached" and again the 
truth which is after godliness_ All
the words of Christ & all doctrines which
are agreeable to his words, and
the precepts, & rules of the gospel, which
describe man's duty, are according
to godliness- or true religion.
They all describe the ways in which

holy love is to be exercised and in which pure obedience to God consists - these ways are all godly & the pure obedience which is yielded to them, is godliness - Hence Godliness includes the exercise of all the christian graces of repentance, faith, love, hope, humility patience, & all others who can be named - likewise, public, private, & secret duties toward God, & all social duties of benevolence towards man - consequently godliness has a glance at, and means comprehensively the sum of true religion - or the duty wh. God requires of man -

 That we may always have the right idea rise in our minds, when the term godliness is used, let it

be remembered that it means a strict, & sincere obedience to words crossed out the precepts of the gospel - Now says the apos in our text, this godliness is profitable (i.e.) useful & tending to the benefit, increase & improvement of all the outward temporal interests of mankind in this life, words crossed out and also their eternal interests & enjoyment of their future life. The life that now is & that which is to come.

He further fixes this profitableness to all things, as invariably certain from the promise of G. - -  He says the practice of godliness, is connected with a promise of profit

It may be useful for us to attend to a number of instances wherein Godliness is profitable in promoting or giving success to temporal pursuits. -

1st  It is profitable in procuring a blessing upon the labours of the husbandman - The husbandman who wishes to obtain a subsistance & the accomodations of life from
the fruits of the field, must necessarily devote a large proportion of his

time to labour - in providing his utensils - clearing, breaking up - & mellowing his ground - casting in his lead - & intlivething? it - also in attending to the state of his flocks & needs, & overseeing the whole compass of his worldly affairs    Now to pursue all this labour in a godly manner: seeking to glorify God ultimately - & looking to this end as the final point of all his pursuits, crossed out word is connected with a promise of God that he shall be blessed in his labours & shall succeed, in acquiring a subsistance & all these
accomodations so far as shall be word crossed out most for his real good in this life. - And he cannot in the exercise of a godly temper, wish for any more -

Says our Savr to his disciples  Seek ye first the Kdom of God, &

his sight & all these things shall be ordered unto you - it may asked here what things? The things to wh. our Lord alluded were the things produced by the labour of the husbandman in the field - What we shall eat, & what we shall drink, & wherewithall we shall be clothed - These things are promised absolutely, such of them as shall be best, to all those who seek ?st? & Kdm of God, and his righss - or which is the same thing - seek those things in a way of Godliness -  In order for the husbandman to labour so as to have godliness profitable to him, he is bound to adhere shirtly to the preceps of the gospel - He is not to be slothful in business, but fervent in spirit serving the Lord.

allow of any deceit, in the service wh. is done for him - nor will he accept of any - He must be thickly honest & upright in his heart - & do to others, as he wants that others should do to him in a change of circumstances -   Further - he must love mercy, be kind to the poor & indigent & be ever ready to help them as God professes him; & also be ready to help the public, as he shall be proffesed and accordingly to the  public exegencies - In addition to this, he must walk with true meekness & humility toward all men; & walk humbly with God - He must likewise preserve hims. fr. intemperance, in all the gratifications of his appetites - & preserve hims. pure & holy, as far as possible - Now Godliness thus interwoven with the labours of Husbandry, will ensure the

the blessing of G. upon them -

into thy house O God

with burnt offerings -  will pay thee thy vows - which my lips have uttered & my mouth hath spoken when I was in trouble -

& he was extolled with my tongue - If I regard iniquity in my heart, the Lord will not hear me - But verily God hath heard me:

me - The word taken in this connection very clearly manifest this  __Idea that if in the offering of our prayers to == God - crossed out we habour any sin in our heart, &

have -  This was manifestly the case with Annanias & Sapphira -  The Evangelist tells us Acts - 5th that a certain man named Annanias with Sapphira his wife sold a possession (as was customary at that day) and brot the price & laid it down at the feet of the Apostles - but through deceit kept back a part of the  price for which their possession sold -
And Peter sd to him  Annanias - why hath Satan filled thy heart to lie to the holy  Ghost.

& to keep back part of the price of the land - Whiles it remained was it not thine own? and after it was sold was it not in thine own power? Why hast thou conceived this thing in thine heart - than hast not lied unto men, but unto God - And Annanias, hearing these words fell down & gave up the ghost - and in the space of about three hours after his wife came in, and not knowing what was done, Peter answered her & sd - Tell me whether ye sold the land for so much, & she sd yea, for so much - Then Peter sd how is it that ye have agreed together to tempt the spirit of the Lord - Behold the feet of them that have buried thy husband are at the door & shall carry thee out: then fell she down straightway

at his feet & yielded up the Ghost - and the younger men came in, & found her dead, & carried her forth & buried her by her husband - And great fear came on all the chh - & upon as many as heard of these things -

This short history, gives us two ?tuiking? instances of those who vowed to devote thems. & all their worldly substance to God - But at the same time regarded iniquity in their hearts: they had ?enet userves? - they were not universal in their dedication.  They were willing to follow the custom of Chs disciples in dedicating thems. to God by public profession - and also follow the custom of selling their worldly interests & laying it at the apos feet: Yet under all this appearance of devotedness to God - they in their hearts, secretly meant not so - their supreme attachment

was still to the world, & they thought they could hide this attachment, & yet keep up appearances of sincerity in their vows - But the Lord   looked through the vile hypocricy and manifested his just indignation in stricking them dead - And grt fear came upon all the chh. in consequence of this awful token of Gods wrath towards these hypocrites - But why did fear, great fear fall upon the Chhs  It was a most solemn lecture to them not to be unto God, in their vows of devoting thems. to him - & all they possessed - They saw in
this event how impossible it was to hide their selfishness fr his eye - & how dangerous it was, to give knowingly but a part of their hearts & possessions when they had vowed to give the whole -

Be careful not to judge in any of these unchristian ways & manners, but shun them, so that you may not be judged & condemned of the Lord for your cruel & malevolent
answer. __  __  It cannot be supposed that our Lord in this text designed to forbid his disciples to exercise their minds in forming candid opinions of men respecting their
moral characters & conduct _ This would interfere with other commands which he had given them; such as to be ware of men to know them by their ?uits? and not to cast
their pearls before swine - & many other which imply the same thing - (viz) their duty to consider & judge of mens  characters and

conduct -  The only thing which was designed to be prohibited in the text was a rash unzouiour? & false judging of MKs & their practice. _ In order therefore to enter directly into our Savrs meaning in the text: it will be necessary for us to consider in the

Ist  Place in a few instances when persons may be said to judge of others in such a manner as to come within the prohibition in the text - judgment and -
II dly  Consider the reasons which our Lord introduced to enforce his prohibition _ to wh. will be added an improvement __
  Ist  If We are to consider in a few instances when persons may be said

to Judge of others & their conduct in such a manner as to come within the prohibition in the text, Judge not &  [?] When persons Judge & condemn all religions sects but their own, & confide & treat them as no christians, but they differ from them in some circumstantials? in outward worship & some trivial speculative points in doctrines then they may be sd to Judge rashly, or censoriously, & come within the prohibition of Ct. in the text - This we find was once the case with Cts immediate dissiples - as may be seen  Luke    9th 49th
And John 2d Master we saw one casting out Devils in thy name, & we forbade him because he followeth not with us - To wh. our Lord replied, forbid him not - for he wh. is not agt us if for us - The disciples

thought it was essential to a persons being friendly to Ct, that he should follow with them, and go about doing miracles in company with them - But in Cts reply he thought them better (viz) that if any man was engaged in his cause & wrought miracles in his name he ==== ought not to be checked in his labours althoh he followed not in company with them - he might be a true disciple notwithstanding. So likewise when persons Judge & condemn all religious sects, but such as follow with them in every particular this is censorious and Judging rashly & strictly forbidden - There is but one essential to salvn, & this is, for the heart to be renewed & sanctified & strictly joined to the Lord so as to be one spirit with him - If a person has this one essential, all other essentials will follow of

cause, and they will certianly be saved - But great numbers of MKd mankind give full & plenary evidence of this sanctification of heart, who still differ in their external modes of worship & in some cases speculative points of doctrine - It is true, there is but one perfectly right way revealed in the word of God; yet this right way, is comprehended even by true christans only in proportion to their capacities & opportunities - & as these differ, it will cause some trifling difference, in their external proceedings - One will think his mode of expressing his offerings before God is the rightest: & another will think his is the rightest, & so on - Yet all may possess the same spirit of union to God - love for his Chr - belief in Ct_ dependance on the atonement for Justification - & zeal for the honor, & glory of God -  This being the case it is very unbecoming for one sect

to Judge & condemn another for small circumstantial differences. This would shew a proud selfsufficient spirit altogether aside fr. t. christian temper.-
The spirit of Gd, & consequently of all who are his, is meek and gentle and disposed to believe the best of all doubtful cases. - But nothing can be more different from this, than a censurious & bitter spirit wh. censures and condemns all who differ from it in unessential matters.-
Again -- When persons condemn a whole sect, or class of professing christians to be hypocrites-- Bece a few among them are manifestly so, is likewise rash Judging, & prohibitted--
It ought always to be remembered that there was a Judas among the disciples of Gd-- that there was a Simon Magus-- Annanias & Sapphira among

t first professors of christianity But there being a Judas did not prove that t rest of the disciples were traitors-- nor were t body of christians proved to be liars agt t Holy Ghost or led by avarice bece because Those distinguished hypocrites, Simon Magus, Annanias, & Sapphira were found among them. The gospel is a different thing from its profession-- It is requisite for every one, by hims. alone to manifests whether he professes t power of it in his heart. If some totally mistake t nature of it, & shew plainly their ignorance of its spirituality & beauty, this but simply proves they are self-deceived & are not what they pretend to be. It does not prove but what thousands beside may be true and good. It would be folly in this case to Judge that all were deceived, & hypocrites bece because some were-- To Judge these would prove a person to be of an inimical ma

levolent spirit wholly aside from the gospel temper--
2dly When persons censure & condemn professors of religion as utterly wicked, bece because they have failings, or have some time or other been guilty of some heinous sin-- then they may be sd to Judge censoriosly, and commit the sin forbidden by Gd. Some will suffer thems. to condemn Moses & Aaron-- & Joshua and Saml & David, & almost all t old testament saints, if they can find any real, or supposed blemish in their [unknown]
So likewise in new testament times, the apostles & primative christians are represented by some in an odious point of light, and every blemish augmented & charged agt them as proofs of their being entirely wicked-- But this is rash Judging-- By dealing out censure agt those whom t word of

Justifies & approves, is in effect discrediting this word, & calling it in question-- This is to rise agt God. & condemn t. approbation which he gives his [unclear]. This is infinitely rash. Admitting that all t. patriarchs had failings -- & that some committed heinous sins-- such as may be found in Noah-- and Lot & Jacob, & Aaron, & David -- & Solomon, & Hezh & Jonah, & Peter among the Apos, Yet does it fr. hence follow that, they were not penitants, & purified from their crime. -- Must their [unclear] be condemned as wicked, bece because they once fell into gross sin? & could repentance never retrieve them or bring them back to holiness? If this were t case no man could ever be saved. There is no such thing as a small sin in Gd [unclear] & who is there who has never sinned? These men were all penitent & good men, and So to Judge they were en

tirely wicked bece because they had some time or other fallen into gross sin is rash, ignorant & malicious. -- It shows that all who Judge them, are wholly unacquainted with their own hearts, & the progress of divine grace in the hearts of others-- As well might they Judge that a man who through his whole life was given to avarice, was really a liberal man, bece because he had done one liberal act, for wh. he was very sorry-- How absurd!! But this is t way, in wh. many Judge of professing christians now. If they can find any blot or wicked thing they have done, they glory in it & condemn them at once as wicked-- although t. most of their lives has been very regular & pious, & bece because none can be found entirely perfect, they Judge there are none good. Perfection is is granted on all hands, is not t.lot of man-- Yet, if profession of religions are imperfect, they are condemned as wicked & mere hypocrites. -- This

is abusive & cruel -- & pointedly prohibitted in our text--
3dly When person charge on each other, with wickedness & evil designs, merely bece they differ in their opinions & practice about t secular concerns of life, then they may be sd to Judge rashly -- & are corrected & reproved by our text -- Mkd Mankind are extremely prone to differ in their opinions relative to their civil interests, such as t laws & constitution they are under -- likewise t conduct of public men, and measures -- likewise t administration of civil Justice between individuals, & t propriety of eachothers conduct in genl -- Now in all these points of interest wherin men are prone to differ they are extremely apt to be censorious & Judge, of eachothers opinions & practice rashly -- & impute wickedness & evil designs to eachother merely bece because they differ

End of the Sermon--
Improvements--
1st This subject sets clearly in our view t care wh Gd. took to guide his disciples in t pure practice of benevolence-- To walk in t. pure ways of benevolence & holiness, is t only method by wh. God can be honored-- t. souls of his childn refreshed, or [unknown] for his Holy Kdm. Kingdom If any of Mkd Mankind have t. [unclear] idea of getting to Hm any other way they will certainly be disappointed-- Indeed, if they have any idea that they may live in t. indulgence of one sin, it will prove all their hopes to be ill founded. On this ground, it was, doubtless, our Lord took such abundant pains to caution his disciples agt error & fatal paths.
2dly We have a good opportunity

to enquire how far we have shuned t error agt wh. Gd warned his disciples -- Do we Judge our brethren of Mkd, Mankind in t. way, wh. are prohibited -- Do we feel disposed to censure & condemn all who differ fr. us, in religious matters or in civil & secular concerns -- Do we make it our practice to treat all, who disagree with us with contempt, & charge them with wickedness & evil designs -- are we deaf to all sides but our own, & furious when opposed? if so-- We doubtless are those who are reproved in our text as Judging rashly--
2dly If we are t. state of those who Judge rashly, we ought to consider that all our censorious speeches & unfriendly accusations stand charged agt us on t. book of God in order to be meted to us again in all their bitterness!

If we have been in this line of proceeding all our lives to this time what a magazine-- what a treasure of wrath have we heaped up for ours. ourselves agt t. day of wrath--? This immense quantity is Just ready to burst over us, & when it comes, how can we endure it? God will make us to eat of t fruit of our own ways & fill us with our own devices-- How Just will this be-- its t measure, wh. we have dealt out to others-- It is the measure we have given ourselves. How can we endure t. thot thought of treating ours. so cruelly?--
There is no way to escape t. impending storm, but by repentance & reformation-- now is t. time Let every one improve it before it is too late--
Especially let t professed dis-

ciples of Gd. take special heed, to shun this destructive evil rash Judging-- let them fear lest through prejudice agt other & rash Judging them they finally shut thems. out of Hn: Heaven When once this is done there can be no entering-- But all such will be turned into a society where malice & slander will have its full scope & torment itself forever--
Again-- Let all be convinced of t absurdity of it-- Study if any rational being would reflect but for a moment he must abhor t. practice, as destructive of all peace for time & eternity. On t. other hand he must admire & approve of a benevolent spirit to do to all as he would be done by. Were this to prevail universally this world become peaceable & happy -- [unclear]

They are prone to be warm, & resolute & determined to carry their points at all events-- feeling as if they knew more & better than all t. world beside, & determined not to rest till all were brot brought to their point of perfection-- Now if there could be found a man or Being who was infinite in wisdom power & goodness, this resolution warmth & determination to bring all to his standard of perfection would be right & very proper. And why consequently is it not right and proper for all men in society now, little and great, to feel this warmth & resolution to bring all to their ideas or points of perfection? (viz.) for this plain reason, bece because all men are not perfect in wisdom power & goodness-- for this reason, it is proper for imperfect beings to have modesty & diffidence towards thems., & candor towards others and not feel & act as if t whole world

must come to their foot. & condemn all who dare rebel--. This spirit of [unclear] ardor & resolution once pervading t. members of society cannot fail to blend it in total anarchy & win. It has done it in a thousand instances & still will.
For as there is every grade of knowledge & capacity among the members of society, each one must have a point of perfection for hims. differing fr. his neighbour, & to this he must yeald all his strength & influence-- t. lesser members must be allowed t. same right to prosecute vigorously t. right of their own consciences as t greatest -- & nothing but universal interference & conflict with one another would succeed-- Since therefore t. members of society are diverse in their gifts & capacities; & all imperfect in some degree; how improper for them to condemn one another merely for their difference of opinions in their secular concerns? How improper for one class to burn

with passion for their own opinions & impute wickedness & evil designs to others who differ fr. them-- When passion, anger, envy, or revenge enter t. heart, t. Judgt is instantly blinded, & turned aside fr. truth. Truth itself looks in such a case like error-- the ears are deaf to any thing but what suits t. passion of t. heart-- & t eyes are blind to every thing, but one side of the question in dispute-- the consequence is rash Judt proceeds and commonly rash conduct. Prejudice blinds all t rational powers, and leads men in t. dark, while they bost boast? and bless thems. for being in t light-- & they will generally triumph, in proportion to the [unclear] & progress of their delusion--
Nothing about men has so ill an appearance, as prejudice-- unbounded self opinion & rashness-- Such persons will Judge rashly & not know it-- They will Judge & decide every thing-- but are totally unable to

examine any thing candidly & hence in every decision they will involve thems. in t guilt of Judging rashly & censoriously-- But in all these instances wherein persons may be sd to Judge one another censoriously-- both in religious & secular concerns, there is nothing wh. forbids their Judging righteous Judt-- If any such in religion, are manifestly unholy, profane, & immoral in their conduct, there can be no harm in Juding Judging them to be wicked, let their profession be what they will-- for says Gd t. tree is known by its fruit-- If a tree bears continually bitter fruit, it is a certain inference that it is a bitter tree-- & hereby t. tree is known-- So with regard to sects & denominations of Christians-- and individuals-- If they generally bear t fruits of sin, & cleave to it this proves they are selfdeceived

All public & private characters are weighed very accurately by the impressions they give, and there can be no harm in receiving these impressions. Our Judgments are formed without thinking of it, in thousands of instances, -- But all wh. was designed designated? to be prohibitted in t. text was a rash, uncandid, malicious & partial Judging of others & their conduct, & being blind to ourselves--
II In the Place we were to consider t. reasons wh. our Lord introduced to enforce his prohibition.
These reasons are two--
1st The danger of it-- Judge not that ye, be not Judged-- If you would not be Judged & condemned your

selves by MKd Mankind, & if you would not be condemned by God at the last day-- then shun this unchristian practice-- For Just so certain as you endulge yourselves in it, & allow yours. in it Just so certain you shall be condemned to everlasting woe-- For says he with what Judgt ye Judge ye shall be Judged-- & with what measure you mete it shall be measured to you again-- Every man therefore who Judges rashly & censoriously of other men, is forming out his own inditement: while he breaths out slander & censure, & reprobates all men & things, which do not happen to suit him; & in giving full scope to all his bitterness & spleen he is forming t. measure of divine wrath wh. he is drawing down upon his own head-- This being t case there is infinite

danger in this practice-- & it would seem as if every one who called hims. a christian, & believed this declaration of Gd, would shudder at a t idea of being found in this guilt, & would shun t. practice wh. lays t. foundation of it-- Indeed it would seem as if every man who believed t. scriptures, & believed in t righteous retributions of the last day would shun this practice-- Our Lord in t. former part of his discourse illustrated & enforced the duty of loving and forgiving enemies, & exercising a benevolent temper: He shewed the utter improbability of any ones being his disciple, or being forgiven of God without this temper-- He keeps up t same idea through his discourse-- A benevolent spirit, is directly opposed to a censorious, bitter, & malevolent spirit. The latter is directly opposed to Gd, to t. law of God, & every precept of t. gospel-- it proves a per-

2d-- Another reason by wh. our Lord enforced his prohibition was t. absurdity of a censorious carping disposition among any who pretended to religion-- And why beholdest thou t. mote that is in thy brothers eye: but considers not t beam that is in thine

own eye. Or how wilt thou say
to thy brother, let me pull out
t. mote out of thine eye, & behold
a beam is in thine own eye.
Thou hypocrite, first cast out
t. beam out of thine own eye, &
then shalt thou see clearly to
cast out t. mote out of thy
brothers eye. The meaning is,
You who are so ready to censure
Judge & condemn t. 
imperfections or sinful inadvertences of
your brethren. How absurd is
it for you to be thus carping &
cruel to their small sins; when
in fact this very dispossition, &
your daily sins are gross, and
unspeakably greater than theirs
wh. offend you.
On how absurd does it look for
you, to go to your brother, and
attempt to correct him for his
little sins while you live, in
abominably gross wickedness.
Thou hypocrite; First get
clear of your own gross sins. Your

unholy conduct, & then you may be
prepared, & there will be some
propriety in your admonishing your
brother, & helping him to purify
hims. fr. his lesser iniquities.
The words mote & beam, were
proverbial among t. Jews for, little
& great sin. The metaphor
wh. our Lord introduces to
illustrate his meaning was very
pertinent, & set t. absurdity of a
censorious spirit in a just point
of light. How perfectly riduculous
would it be for an Occulist to
pretend that he saw a small mote
in his neighbour's eye, when he hims.
was really blind with a beam in
his own, he would render himself contemptable. But
This is really t. case
with prejudiced carpers? at other
men's failings,
they think they see
many motes or sins in their neighbours,
but are blind to their own 
enormities. While they are thus
blind to their crimes,
how contemptable do they

appear in reproving others for their
imperfections. Like a blind
overlift attempting to extract a
mote fr. t. eye of one who was
not blind. Our Lord
pronounces such a censorious Judge
an hypocrite, & exhorts him
to be more consistent, & first
get t. beam out of his own eye
or repent of his own heinous guilt, &
then, he may be prepared assist
his neighbours to correct their
faults. This reason likewise
is very forcible to excite t. attention
of all who have any pretentions
to being disciples of Ct., or sense
of propriety, to shun a carping
spirit, & not indulge thems. in
judging rashly, for the moment
they do this, they condemn thems.
& prove thems. Hypocrites, &
expose thems. to t. just abhorrence
of God & men.
